6.74.text: - Thanks for having me, thanks for the introduction Tina.

9.77.text: It's so great to be back on campus.

10.88.text: I was reflecting yesterday that it has been indeed

13.05.text: nine years since I took the design class

15.93.text: that Embrace came out of, so I'm feeling extra old today.

19.30.text: So I'd like you guys to go through an exercise with me

25.17.text: and hold out your hands in front of you.

31.02.text: And imagine what you could place inside your hands.

44.74.text: What you see here is a premature baby.

46.47.text: He looks like he's resting peacefully when in fact

48.53.text: he is struggling to stay alive,

50.38.text: because he can't regulate his own body temperature.

53.55.text: Sadly, there are millions of babies like this

55.32.text: born every year around the world.

57.43.text: In fact, 15 million pre-term and underweight babies

62.76.text: Three million babies die in the first 28 days of their life.

70.76.text: these babies face is staying warm,

72.44.text: and that is the primary function of an incubator.

75.33.text: But incubators are expensive, they cost $20,000 upwards,

78.51.text: they require a constant supply of electricity,

80.89.text: they're difficult to operate, so you're not going to find

83.57.text: them in rural areas where many of these babies are dying.

87.37.text: In 2007 while I was doing my MBA here at Stanford,

90.63.text: I took a class at the design school that would completely

94.57.text: Many of you may be familiar with it,

96.89.text: but Design for Extreme Affordability brings together

98.23.text: students of all the different graduate programs

101.24.text: with the goal of creating low-cost technologies for people

103.47.text: living on less than a dollar a day.

106.88.text: The challenge posed to my team at the time

108.13.text: was to build a baby incubator that cost less

110.79.text: than 1% of the cost of a traditional incubator,

114.06.text: which in the U.S. is about $20,000.

116.61.text: So the first thing we did was to go on the ground

119.53.text: to places like Nepal, and Uganda,

122.36.text: and this is what we would often see.

125.04.text: So this is a hospital, neonatal intensive care unit

128.87.text: Every baby in here is in need of incubation.

131.22.text: And then you have a donated incubator

133.57.text: sitting in the corner of the room that's empty.

137.37.text: There's no electricity to power it,

139.62.text: no one has been trained on how to use it.

141.70.text: If a part breaks there are no spare parts for replacement.

145.33.text: So even when these incubators are free,

148.31.text: they're not usable because of all these systemic issues.

153.44.text: Instead people use solutions like this,

155.29.text: these are old space heaters used to warm babies.

157.64.text: You put your hand in front of one of these and you'll

159.84.text: immediately feel it starting to burn.

163.86.text: These are the most common solution in India,

166.38.text: where 40% of all the world's premature babies are born.

168.86.text: But in every clinic I visited

170.51.text: you hear stories of lightbulbs shattering

172.68.text: over these babies because of problems with the circuits,

174.93.text: so completely unsafe and ineffective solutions out there.

178.54.text: From there we traveled to the villages,

181.47.text: and that's where I truly began to understand the problem.

183.96.text: This is Sujatha, this is one of the first women I met

186.67.text: in a village in South India.

188.85.text: Sujatha gave birth to her baby two months prematurely.

192.83.text: She took her baby to a village doctor

194.48.text: who advised her to go to a city hospital

196.50.text: so her baby could be placed in an incubator.

198.77.text: That hospital was over four hours away

201.60.text: and she didn't have the money to get there.

207.18.text: And since then I've heard dozens of similar stories.

210.27.text: But it was based on stories like that that we realized,

212.38.text: what was needed was not just a lower cost version

214.73.text: of what exists today, we needed something that could

216.86.text: function without a constant supply of electricity

219.74.text: that would be easy enough for a mother or a midwife

222.03.text: or a healthcare worker in a village setting to use.

225.56.text: So coming back to Stanford, we went to the drawing board.

227.45.text: We wanted something super intuitive to use,

230.40.text: so we created a sleeping bag design.

232.86.text: These are literally our first sketches of the product

235.49.text: on the back of a napkin.

237.34.text: And then we thought what could maintain heat

239.14.text: at a constant temperature without the need for electricity.

242.29.text: We went back to high school physics, to the concept

245.44.text: that when a material changes phases,

247.32.text: let's say from a solid to a liquid, or a liquid to a solid,

250.39.text: it does so at one constant temperature.

253.33.text: What if we could find a material that melted at human body

255.82.text: temperature, and then put enough of that substance in

258.50.text: that that melting period took place over hours at a time.

263.77.text: We didn't know what that material was,

265.40.text: so we prototyped with the closest thing we could find.

267.74.text: This is butter in ziplock bags.

269.70.text: We made quite a mess at the D School.

271.20.text: From there we went to a Salvation Army,

273.67.text: and we bought everything baby related we could find

276.24.text: and literally started duct taping our first

279.68.text: So if you can see here, our first prototype had a tube

282.98.text: going down the side of the sleeping bag where you would

285.71.text: pour the boiling water and that would melt

289.57.text: Then we showed this to some people and they said to us

291.22.text: it's probably not a good idea to put boiling water

294.45.text: right next to a baby's head.

295.92.text: So we quickly scrapped that and moved on

300.65.text: Here we realized that babies in these countries

302.37.text: often don't wear diapers, so we needed something,

304.41.text: a material that was waterproof and really easy to wipe down.

307.40.text: Those were the materials we identified here.

311.34.text: And then with those early prototypes we went back to India,

313.75.text: showed them to mothers, to doctors,

316.16.text: to health care workers, and with their feedback

318.80.text: we continued to iterate on the design.

322.30.text: We realized the importance of sterility.

324.25.text: Because these are all reusable we didn't want babies to

326.33.text: cross-infect each other if they were sick.

328.79.text: So we ended up creating this sleeping bag out of one

331.23.text: entire piece of fabric where there are limited seams

333.30.text: on the inside where dirt can collect.

336.46.text: Here doctors requested a clear viewing window so they

339.45.text: could observe the baby's breathing and color more easily.

343.85.text: And then this was one of my favorite stories.

346.38.text: So on the wax pouch, there is a temperature indicator.

349.31.text: It's a liquid crystal display that changes color

353.62.text: so you know when it's too hot or too cold.

355.35.text: And as we showed this to the mothers in villages,

359.45.text: They would say to us, we don't trust Western medicine.

363.15.text: If you gave me a dosage of medicine for my baby.

365.49.text: I would cut it in half because it's too strong.

368.76.text: So if you told me to keep this at 37 degrees Celsius,

370.79.text: or 98 degrees fahrenheit, I'd keep it at a little less

373.23.text: than that because that's probably too warm.

376.10.text: So that led to a very important design decision

378.73.text: to make it a binary happy face frowning face

383.42.text: I think that that's really the key to great design,

384.97.text: is empathy and all of these nuances

390.88.text: When we needed to do more testing,

392.89.text: we used our own family members.

395.60.text: that I stuffed into one of the early prototypes.

400.49.text: And so it was in this way

401.32.text: that we tested and retested hundreds of times

404.34.text: over the course of several years

410.15.text: I've got it with me here today.

414.83.text: So this is the Embrace Warmer, as you can see

416.55.text: it looks like a little sleeping bag

419.39.text: You've got the clear viewing window here,

421.27.text: and in the back, you've got this pouch of wax

425.90.text: that can be melted either with boiling water

428.46.text: or with a short burst of electricity

430.87.text: for places that do have intermittent access to electricity.

433.53.text: And once melted it stays at the exact same temperature

435.77.text: for up to eight hours at a stretch.

438.57.text: And this can be reheated thousands of times.

441.86.text: So you put it into a little pocket in the back

443.85.text: and it creates a warm microenvironment for the baby.

445.65.text: I'm going to pass this around so you guys can

447.56.text: play around with it a bit.

452.34.text: So I still remember in 2011 as we were launching the product

455.86.text: in those weeks leading up to our product launch,

458.31.text: everything that could have possibly gone wrong went wrong.

461.87.text: The electricity in our manufacturing facility went out

466.63.text: a part of our product got stuck in customs

470.93.text: because the wash tags were sewn incorrectly,

473.13.text: but somehow we managed to get that first product

475.66.text: ready to ship to our first customer.

478.44.text: And then on the way to that doctor's office,

483.34.text: So the whole team jumped out,

484.66.text: we piled into this auto-rickshaw that you see here,

486.86.text: and we delivered our first product.

489.94.text: I always tell the story because it's so representative

491.66.text: to me of what entrepreneurship is all about,

494.47.text: which is doing whatever it takes to get past the obstacles

496.92.text: that come in your way and finally reach that end goal.

502.15.text: And here is our very first customer.

506.06.text: The most exciting part of this journey by far,

509.27.text: has been getting this product into the hands of the families

512.30.text: and the babies who need it the most.

513.81.text: And we have been so lucky to get the support

517.53.text: from people of all different walks of life,

519.95.text: who really rallied behind us to help make an impact

524.82.text: Which really led me to believe this quote from

528.91.text: He says "When you truly believe something,

530.68.text: "the universe will conspire to help you achieve it."

533.97.text: A few years ago we were invited to present our work

537.05.text: to President Obama at the White House,

538.97.text: and that got great visibility for our efforts.

540.97.text: We presented a commitment at the Clinton Global Initiative

544.49.text: as well and formed some great partnerships through that.

546.90.text: In 2014 Beyonce made a donation to us,

550.28.text: a surprise donation that got our products

552.41.text: into nine countries across Sub-Saharan Africa.

555.96.text: So with the help of all of these people,

557.90.text: to date we have been able to help over 200,000 babies.

562.02.text: The product is now in 20 countries,

564.11.text: and I'd like to share just a few of the stories

570.02.text: So this is one of my all-time favorite stories,

575.35.text: About four years ago we started working with

579.54.text: A day after we delivered our product,

581.00.text: they called us telling us they had found

583.83.text: a two-pound baby that was abandoned

585.57.text: on a street in central China.

590.44.text: kept him in the warmer for about 30 days,

592.36.text: it was a very scary period for all of us,

594.90.text: we weren't sure if he was going to survive or not.

598.55.text: Seven months later I went to visit the orphanage,

600.56.text: and I got to hold Nathan in my arms,

602.62.text: he was this vibrant, interactive little boy,

605.34.text: and it was a very very special experience.

607.83.text: The orphanage told me this was the first time

610.22.text: a baby of this size had ever survived there.

613.35.text: A few months after this we got an email

617.71.text: saying they had adopted this little boy

620.01.text: and were traveling to Beijing that summer to bring him home.

623.90.text: So here Nathan is with his new family.

628.08.text: we sent him a warmer for his birthday.

630.24.text: You can tell he's outgrown it by just a little bit.

635.11.text: And the next story I'm going to show a short video.

804.72.text: - So it's just a few more pictures of the product

807.59.text: This is twins in Uganda while using the Embrace Warmer,

812.54.text: These are some images of the product being used

817.07.text: So it's been incredibly rewarding and exciting to be a part

820.89.text: of this effort and to create this type of impact.

824.75.text: But I would be lying if I were to tell you

826.69.text: that it was all roses and flowers and

828.54.text: that we didn't face some extreme challenges along the way.

832.23.text: It's always wonderful to have a vision

833.99.text: of what you want to do,

838.35.text: "Everyone has a plan until they get punched in the mouth."

841.76.text: This has happened to us repeatedly.

843.83.text: I could tell you about our challenges for days.

847.23.text: But I'll tell you about one pivotal moment for us

850.20.text: that really kind of redefined the business,

852.62.text: and taught me a lot about life as well.

855.91.text: So in 2014 I had lived in India for four years.

859.22.text: I moved back to the U.S. and at that time

861.71.text: we had been working on a global distribution

863.84.text: and financing deal with a major medical device company.

867.76.text: I had been working on this deal day and night

870.38.text: for almost a year at that point,

872.22.text: and then about a week away from signing the deal,

875.31.text: we found out that this company let go of their

878.32.text: healthcare CEO, who was the main advocate for the deal,

881.67.text: and they pulled the plug on our financing.

884.03.text: We had seven days of cash left in the bank,

890.77.text: I had no idea what we gonna do.

891.77.text: All of us thought we were gonna have to

898.16.text: I had gone to the World Economic Forum at Davos,

900.99.text: and one morning I went to a meditation session,

904.94.text: which maybe five out of 3,000 people showed up for.

907.18.text: And I happened to sit next to Marc Benioff,

910.61.text: who is the founder and CEO of Salesforce.

914.70.text: Marc and I started talking, after the meditation session

918.18.text: and I shared with him my work at Embrace.

920.05.text: Coincidentally, he was about to make a donation

923.06.text: to create the Preterm Birth Initiative at USCF

926.70.text: in partnership with the Gates Foundation.

930.00.text: So if there were anything in the world

931.89.text: that would make me believe in serendipity,

932.94.text: it was the universe seating me next to this man.

936.28.text: I kept in touch with Marc, and when this crisis hit,

939.16.text: I sent him an urgent email telling him

941.74.text: what had happened, asking for his help.

944.59.text: John Hennessy was one of our advisors,

946.25.text: also reached out to Marc asking for his help.

948.71.text: And a few days later, he wrote back

950.28.text: generously agreeing to fund the company.

954.08.text: So I'm just so indebted to Marc for saving the company,

958.14.text: we would have had to close our doors if it weren't for that.

962.47.text: And it was a really pivotal experience

965.57.text: in a number of different ways,

967.74.text: but one of the things it forced me to do at that point

970.66.text: was to take a step back and really re-evaluate our strategy.

973.87.text: You know, at the time we were selling our product

983.02.text: you don't know when the contracts are going to come through,

984.77.text: when you're going to get paid.

986.04.text: It wasn't leading to a sustainable business model.

989.48.text: At the same time I had started to look at models

991.69.text: like Tom Shoes and Warby Parker,

995.21.text: what if we could leverage our technology

996.71.text: and create a product for the U.S. market

998.67.text: and then use the profits from that

1001.93.text: to fund the expansion of the Embrace Warmers

1007.15.text: And so that led to the birth of our newest initiative

1012.02.text: I was just laughing to myself as I was preparing

1014.63.text: this presentation because this was coincidental,

1016.49.text: but a lotus, the representation of a lotus,

1020.16.text: it's a flower that comes from these dark and muddy waters

1025.34.text: So from all the chaos that we've experienced,

1027.20.text: we came up with this really cool product.

1029.71.text: And what it is, it's a line of baby products

1032.27.text: for the U.S. market, so sleeping bags, swaddles

1034.87.text: and blankets that have a technology akin

1038.85.text: The fabric of these products is lined with microns of wax.

1043.64.text: So this was first used in NASA spacesuits.

1045.51.text: And what it does it serves to absorb or release heat

1049.27.text: to keep babies at an ideal skin temperature,

1054.50.text: Our informal studies have shown that babies sleep on average

1057.43.text: an hour longer with our product versus existing products,

1062.05.text: But the real impetus for doing this was to implement a

1068.57.text: So for every Little Lotus that we sell here in the U.S.,

1070.48.text: we help to save a life in a developing country

1075.27.text: And I think the ethos behind doing this,

1077.59.text: as I came back to the U.S. and started doing research,

1080.14.text: I talked to lots of parents, and moms in particular.

1083.79.text: I would often hear them say to me,

1085.18.text: you know when I became a mother for the first time,

1087.18.text: I felt an instant comraderie with every other mother

1090.09.text: in the world, and if I saw a baby in need,

1092.80.text: I would do anything to help that child.

1096.14.text: So we really wanted to create a global community

1101.78.text: Another cool aspect of the Little Lotus, you will notice

1105.91.text: that there are handprints all over

1107.54.text: the front panel of the product,

1110.01.text: and that comes from an artwork called Touch Our Future,

1112.03.text: so I collaborated with another Stanford alum,

1114.92.text: Drue Kataoka, she's an amazing artist,

1117.50.text: and her concept was to collect the hand traces

1121.05.text: of mothers and babies from all over the world.

1124.16.text: From 14 countries, many of whom have been directly

1128.88.text: In addition to that, we got the hand traces

1131.17.text: of the Dalai Lama and about 20 Nobel Peace Prize Laureates,

1134.44.text: and a bunch of Hollywood celebrities as well.

1137.67.text: So it's been a really fun way for people to literally

1139.71.text: lend their hand to this cause.

1144.59.text: our hope is that over the next few years

1146.87.text: we are able to reach 1.000.000 babies

1150.57.text: with the Embrace Warmers and truly get the product

1152.73.text: into the hands of every baby and every family who needs it.

1157.53.text: So that is my story, that is the last 10 years of my life.

1161.22.text: And this is where we're at today.

1163.76.text: And I thought I would end by just sharing a few

1165.50.text: of the key lessons that I have learned in this journey.

1171.45.text: So the first lesson is to lead with the WHY.

1173.76.text: I got this from Simon Sinek's TED talk.

1175.77.text: If you haven't watched it I really recommend it.

1177.16.text: Why do you do what you do?

1180.91.text: And how does this align with your own purpose

1183.84.text: And this is so much more important than what you do

1187.43.text: And I think being really rooted in your purpose

1189.72.text: and being clear about that why,

1191.87.text: it will get you through your toughest moments

1193.69.text: and get you through all those obstacles

1197.37.text: And at the same time it will allow you to inspire others

1199.02.text: and rally people behind your cause,

1202.37.text: so give a lot of thought to why it is you want to do

1206.85.text: My second lesson here, from Winston Churchill who said

1210.92.text: "Success is not final, failure is not fatal.

1214.30.text: "It is the courage to continue that counts."

1217.56.text: And I have a picture of me surfing here,

1218.99.text: because this is a sport I picked up

1220.51.text: about a year and a half ago,

1221.69.text: that I have become completely obsessed with.

1224.09.text: One of the things about surfing,

1225.87.text: it's so humbling, because most of the time

1228.38.text: I'm not on my board, I'm falling off my board,

1230.82.text: and having to find the courage to get back on,

1233.12.text: and paddle back out for the next wave.

1235.90.text: And to me, this is the most important trait

1245.52.text: And you need to have the courage and that persistence

1247.69.text: to get back out there, learn from your mistakes,

1251.92.text: The other, related thing I've learned

1254.90.text: from surfing and the ocean, is this idea of impermanence.

1258.85.text: Everything in this world is constantly changing.

1261.99.text: And nothing teaches you that more than being in the ocean,

1265.00.text: where your conditions are changing minute to minute,

1268.13.text: and what that's taught me about

1272.10.text: to not be attached to anything, including an outcome.

1276.47.text: I think I had become so attached to this end outcome

1278.88.text: for Embrace, that the thought of the company

1281.78.text: shutting down in that story I told you,

1284.18.text: really threatened my own sense of identity,

1286.93.text: and what I learned from that process

1289.07.text: is that we are not defined by our successes or our failures,

1293.16.text: we are defined by our values

1295.99.text: and by the journey that we take.

1297.32.text: So as cliche as it sounds,

1299.04.text: the journey is truly more important than the destination.

1302.71.text: Make sure you're having fun in that journey

1308.51.text: And my last lesson here, is to choose to see the world

1314.07.text: Because we get to choose the perspective

1315.74.text: by which we see the world.

1317.83.text: After living in India for a few years,

1319.66.text: I could see myself becoming jaded,

1323.58.text: I was dealing with some of the most vulnerable populations

1326.02.text: in the world and saw so many sad things.

1330.07.text: I was working in a very corrupt and broken system.

1332.73.text: And then at some point I caught myself.

1335.33.text: I realized that for every horrible thing that I saw,

1337.94.text: I saw something equally as beautiful.

1341.07.text: All of the wonderful people who had come together to help us

1343.65.text: in this cause, all of the noble doctors I met

1346.00.text: who stayed up all night in these villages to see patients.

1349.32.text: The most beautiful thing I got to see in my work

1351.89.text: was a love a parent has for their child.

1355.13.text: It's the purest and most selfless form of love in the world,

1358.04.text: and I realized that a mother, no matter how poor

1360.73.text: or uneducated or impoverished, will do anything

1367.50.text: And that's the beauty I got to see every day in my work.

1371.00.text: So I encourage you to see the world

1372.34.text: through the lens of beauty, because that will give you

1374.76.text: the optimism to keep changing the world.

1380.15.text: And I wanted to leave you with one last thought.

1383.96.text: So this is the Milan Cathedral.

1385.29.text: The great cathedrals of Europe were built over centuries,

1389.26.text: this one the construction began in 1385,

1395.61.text: What that meant is oftentimes the people who

1397.49.text: spent their whole lives working on these cathedrals

1399.67.text: never lived to see the fruits of their labor,

1402.11.text: nor did their children, nor did their grandchildren.

1406.25.text: So why did they dedicate themselves so tirelessly

1412.15.text: I believe it was because they believed in a cause

1413.75.text: that was far greater than themselves.

1417.63.text: So I ask each of you to think about,

1419.09.text: what is the cathedral that you want to build?

1421.63.text: And what is the legacy that you want to leave?

1423.87.text: My cathedral is a place where no baby dies from being cold.

1429.19.text: It's a place where every parent is empowered

1431.50.text: to save their child, and it's a place

1434.28.text: where the brightest minds come together

1436.10.text: to change the world for the better.

1438.41.text: One baby step at a time.

1452.94.text: - [Tina] So, would you take some questions please?

1455.67.text: - [Student] You said that Beyonce gave a donation

1461.43.text: but your company also was funded,

1462.44.text: so can you clarify whether it's a non profit

1467.11.text: - [Student] And then the reasons behind choosing, you know.

1469.74.text: So we started as a non-profit, as a 501(c)(3), in 2008

1472.57.text: that's when we first started out.

1474.91.text: In 2011 we actually spun out a for-profit arm

1478.78.text: and the idea was that the for-profit

1481.06.text: would sell the product to governments and emerging markets

1484.12.text: and then pay a royalty fee to the non-profit.

1486.75.text: We really hoped that that would create

1490.17.text: at the time a lot of impact investors were coming into play

1494.36.text: as well, encouraging us to explore a for-profit route,

1497.34.text: which is an easier way to raise capital.

1498.94.text: So the real reason for doing it was

1500.62.text: so we could leverage both philanthropic capital

1502.68.text: to donate the product to the poorest places,

1506.81.text: to do the more capital intensive parts of our work.

1512.56.text: - [Male Student] Can you speak to the design constraints

1514.99.text: or some of the thinking behind going down this approach

1518.72.text: versus something like NeoNurture, which is basically

1523.25.text: an incubator run by a car battery
